awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Eocene perspective on future recovery rates of climate and ocean chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This projects provides a case study of a past climate event, called the Eocene Thermal Maximum-2 to constrain natural recovery rates of climate and ocean chemistry following massive carbon input into Earth's surface reservoirs. The study will allow new insight into past climate and ocean acidification processes that were hitherto unexplored, hence promoting the progress of science and advancing the field of climatology. Such insight is essential to providing the public, scientific leaders, and policy makers with a better understanding of the consequences of unabated CO2 emissions for global climate, ocean carbonate chemistry, and marine ecosystems. Moreover, the project integrates research and educational activities by introducing this information directly into secondary school and college curricula and popular journals. The project fosters education for graduate and undergraduate students from ethnically diverse populations, while conducting cutting-edge research at the same time. The outcome of this study will advancethe understanding of the Earth system and hence improve forecasts of future climate change, which is beneficial to society.

Specifically, proxy records will be generated and used (d13C, d18O, %CaCO3, B/Ca, d11B) in combination with numerical modeling to determine natural recovery times for carbon cycle processes, temperature, and surface ocean acidification. The study will (1) provide fundamental insight into negative climate-carbon cycle feedbacks, (2) address important gaps in data coverage and understanding of Eocene hyperthermals, and (3) constrain critical parameter values needed for future climate-carbon cycle simulations.

por.por_cntn:
The early Eocene epoch (56-52 Ma) was characterized by a number of natural ocean acidification events that led to the dissolution of carbonate sediments at the bottom of the ocean, global warming, and in some cases to extinction and subsequent evolution in marine ecosystems. By studying this ancient events, we can learn about the Earth’s response to rapid warming and ocean acidification, and in particular the time that it takes the Earth system to recover from such carbon cycle perturbations.  

This project performed boron isotope analyses for a collaborative project that studies ocean acidification, warming and Earth system recovery across Eocene Thermal Maximum 2 (ETM-2), a carbon cycle perturbation event that happened ~54 million years ago (Ma). This event is the second largest hyperthermal at that time and follows the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (~56 Ma), which had already been studied for the same environmental parameters in an earlier project. The boron isotope ratio in marine calcium carbonates records seawater acidity, and when measured in the fossil shells of planktic foraminifera (i.e., a group of single-celled calcifying animals) allows to reconstruct surface ocean acidity.

While companion geochemical analyses and modeling are still ongoing at UC Santa Cruz and the University of Hawai’i, respectively, the boron isotope analyses are completed and demonstrate that ocean acidification across ETM-2 was more than half that of the earlier PETM. This is a surprising result because warming and the associated negative carbon isotope excursion (an indicator of carbon addition from a dormant reservoir like methane hydrates, fossil organic carbon or volcanism) were only approximately half that of the PETM, and sedimentary calcium carbonate dissolution was also less pronounced. Using carbon cycle models, the magnitudes of warming, carbon isotope excursion and CaCO3 dissolution translate to less than half as much ocean acidification across ETM-2 than across the PETM, but our reconstructions suggest acidification was almost 2/3 of that across the PETM. Combining this acidification with the carbon isotope excursion suggests an organic carbon source (with a higher carbon isotopic composition than that of a methane source) as the trigger of the event.

Additional boron isotope data spanning the transition between PETM and ETM-2 are somewhat lower than data collected immediately before the two events, suggesting that seawater was more acidic during the transition and then briefly became more alkaline directly before the events. These data have been collected from two sediment core sites, one in the equatorial Pacific and the other in the eastern South Atlantic, indicating that our data reflect a global signal and not a post-depositional alteration of original geochemical data at just one location. In summary, while models and data agree qualitatively in terms of surface ocean acidification, they do not agree quantitatively. This could indicate either that Eocene boron isotope data are amplified by effects that have not yet been calibrated or identified, that regional geochemical influences came into play at both observation sites, or that the models do not yet capture all aspects of early Eocene carbon cycling. Our research team is still discussing these scenarios as we prepare the last data for publication.

Training young scientists and public outreach:

This project allowed the training of two graduate students, who have been guided to design and perform the geochemical analyses, interpret data and bring them to publication. In addition, results from this study have been incorporated in lectures at the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology, in public lectures, and in several presentations at international conferences and universities.
